Published by Elsevier Inc. 2024-10-07T09:09:59.032Z http://vtw.elsevier.com/data/voc/AddOnTypes/50.7/aggregated-refined Netherlands Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy NWO Nederlandse Organisatie voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100003246 http://sws.geonames.org/2750405 ARC ARC Australian Research Council http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100000923 http://sws.geonames.org/2077456/ Utrecht University UU Universiteit Utrecht http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100001829 http://sws.geonames.org/2750405/ Advanced Research Center for Chemical Building Blocks This paper is dedicated to the memory of Sebastian Haben, who unexpectedly passed away during the final year of his PhD. He had a big heart and made a lasting impact on everyone he met. As an excellent young scientist, he was working on improving solid catalysts for methane dehydroaromatization using operando UV-Vis spectroscopy. Sebastian was the driving force of many initiatives both at group and institute level - activities that were always motivated by his wish to help others. He was a strong advocate for Open Science, so by publishing his work, we hope this contribution can help further the field. Jim de Ruiter (Utrecht University) is acknowledged for measuring Raman spectroscopy and Sebastian Rejman (Utrecht University) is acknowledged for measuring TGA. Scheme 1 Phases of the Methane Dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction, which have been studied using operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) in combination with a Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS) analysis. (A) Activation period: Reduction of oxidic pre-catalyst to an (oxy-)carbidic active form. (B) Induction/active period: Conversion of CH4 into hydrocarbon pool (HCP) species, which produces benzene and H2, next to other base chemicals, such as higher and/or substituted aromatics. (C) Deactivation period: Further conversion of CH4 results in the formation of polyaromatic species and carbon deposits, thereby blocking access to the active site. Scheme 2 Spectral assignment of the UV–Vis region of the hydrocarbon pool species active in the methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) reaction. Operando UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy insights into the methane dehydroaromatization reaction over Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts Sebastian Haben Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization Josepha J.G. Graphical abstract Methane Dehydroaromatization (MDA) is proposed as a possible way to valorize stranded natural gas, e.g., arising during crude oil drilling. In this study, we used operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) in combination with Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS) to distinguish the MDA reaction phases of activation, induction, and deactivation. We identified three spectral components, which describe these distinct reaction phases. When the catalyst was activated in CO, two spectral components alone sufficiently described the operando UV–Vis DRS data. We further found that the preparation method of the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst has little influence on the observed spectral features. However, the different preparation methods impact the dispersion of Mo, resulting in faster deactivation for the catalyst with more Mo-clusters compared to the catalyst with a higher Mo dispersion. This study shows that operando UV–Vis DRS in combination with the MCR-ALS methodology is a powerful analytical tool to disentangle and study the three MDA reaction phases. Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Mo/HZSM-5 Operando UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy Reaction phases Coke deposition Data availability The data used in this paper has been uploaded to the YODA repository and are available under: https://doi.org/10.24416/UU01-OP0RKY. 1 Introduction Flaring, the burning of unwanted combustible gases that escape during crude oil extraction, has not only been linked to negative health effects and environmental pollution for surrounding communities, but also presents a potentially avoidable greenhouse gas emission [1–4]. By estimates of the World bank, roughly 139millionm3 of natural gas was flared in 2022, which is almost equal to the total annual natural gas consumption of Middle and South America or Africa in 2021 [5]. One of the suggested solutions to reduce the amount of flared gas is the conversion to useful chemicals, which are preferably liquids so they can be easily transported over long distances [2,6]. Several possible routes are conceivable to achieve this goal. For example, the gas-to-liquid reaction or oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), but this reaction suffers from a low atom efficiency due to a thermodynamic preference to form CO2 [7,8]. Alternatively, methane can be transformed in a non-oxidative route to valuable platform base chemicals, like benzene, with hydrogen as the main non-carbon-containing product [7–9] in the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction. While several transition metal oxides supported zeolites are active for the MDA reaction, the Mo/H-ZSM-5 material appears to be the most active solid catalyst for the reaction [10–15]. During the reaction, three distinct phases, namely activation, induction, and deactivation, were identified, which are illustrated in Scheme 1 . During the activation period, the oxidic pre-catalyst is reduced either directly with CH4 or with CO to form the active (oxy-)carbidic Mo, which can activate the C–H bond of CH4 [9,13,16,17]. The activation of the solid catalyst has been thoroughly investigated by a variety of mostly ex situ and in situ characterization methods. In 1995, it was already shown with X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) that the partial reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ is required for the formation of hydrocarbon products [18]. Another study at this time showed that the partial oxidation of Mo2C/ZSM-5 led to higher activities [19]. More recently, operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and pulsed analytical techniques have been used and it was found that the (oxy-)carbidic character of the Mo phase could be unequivocally identified at reaction conditions [20,21]. After the active catalyst is formed, the induction period starts which is marked by the steady increase in benzene yield up to a certain maximum. In 1999, it was already highlighted that the carbonaceous deposits formed during the induction period could play a key role in the MDA reaction [22]. Although several other reaction and/or deactivation mechanisms have been proposed in the literature, involving C2 intermediates [12,23–25], it was also hypothesized that the MDA reaction undergoes a similar mechanism as the methanol-to-hydrocarbon (MTH) reaction which involves the formation of a hydrocarbon pool (HCP) [26–28]. One of the questions that remains is if similar hydrocarbon species as in the MTH process are indeed involved in the MDA reaction. Kosinov et al. hypothesized that large coke-like radicals might be the source of the aromatic products, but it is still unclear how these molecules are precisely formed. In contrast, Gao et al. recently identified small olefins as the source of the produced benzene, similar to what occurs in the aromatic cycle of the MTH reaction [29]. Finally, the deactivation period is mainly governed by the formation of large polyaromatics deposits on the surface and inside the zeolite’s pores, blocking access to the active sites. On top of that, the anchoring strength of Mo-carbide particles on the external zeolite surface is lowered due to the formation of these polyaromatic species leading to the sintering of the Mo particles [30]. It was demonstrated that the structure of the pre-catalyst is crucial to reduce the formation of coke deposits. While well-dispersed Mo-centres within the zeolite channels lead to less coke formation, larger Mo nanoparticles on the (outer) zeolite surface result in more coke formation [31]. To prevent this, the dispersion of Mo over the zeolite should be controlled which can be achieved during the synthesis. It was shown that impregnation leads to better dispersed Mo, compared to solid-ion exchange, which eventually results in higher activity [10,32,33]. Another method to prevent the formation of larger Mo particles is carburizing Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts before the reaction. This resulted in a less mobile Mo phase which contributed to higher catalyst stability [34]. Although several aspects of the MDA reaction, like catalyst activation, are well understood on a macro- and microscopic level, there is still a considerable lack of fundamental understanding about the induction and deactivation processes of the MDA reaction, especially under operando measurement conditions. Due to the proposed possible mechanistic similarity of the MDA and MTH reactions, similar analytical tools used to study the MTH reaction might prove beneficial in providing further insight into the MDA reaction and the potential involvement of the hydrocarbon pool species. Operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) has proven useful in identifying the important HCP species in the MTH mechanism, which provided interesting handles for catalyst design to tune product formation [35–37]. In this study, we apply this analytical method to the MDA process. For the MDA reaction, operando UV–Vis spectroscopy brings poses additional challenges. MDA is carried out at higher reaction temperatures compared to the MTH reaction, which causes black body radiation. This leads to saturation of the spectra at wavenumbers below 12500 cm−1, so only the data between 42000–12500 cm−1 was used. In addition, for the MDA reaction, we could not measure distinct absorption bands in the operando UV–Vis DRS due to convolution of the various hydrocarbon species. Therefore, following the evolution of different classes of molecules, which might contribute to the HCP or the formation of coke deposits, from the spectra directly is challenging. To facilitate this, all collected operando UV–Vis DRS data were analyzed with the Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternate Least Square (MCR-ALS) routine. This method has proven capable of elucidating important intermediates during the activation of Mo/H-ZSM-5 and Fe/H-ZSM-5 during MDA (using operando XAS data), as well as gaining insights from operando UV–Vis DRS data of the deactivation process of the similar MTH reaction [35,38]. Hence, we have combined operando UV–Vis DRS with MCR-ALS to study important hydrocarbon species and possible (pre-)coke species that play a role during activation, induction, and deactivation in the MDA reaction. We also used this analytical approach to investigate the effect of a CO pre-treatment as well as the role of catalyst preparation. As a result, new mechanistic insights into this important catalyst system have been obtained. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Two samples have been prepared via two different routes starting from a commercial NH4-ZSM-5 sample (Zeolyst CBV2314, surface are of 397 m2/g, pore volume of 0.24 cm3/g) with a theoretical Si/Al ratio of 11.5. The first route involved solid-state ion exchange (SIE), while the second one involved incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). Before the synthesis, the zeolite material was transformed to its protonic form by calcination at 550 °C (2 °C/min heating ramp) for 7 h in a static air furnace. For the sample prepared through IWI (2MoHZ-IWI), 2.0 g of the H-ZSM-5 material was dried at 120 °C under dynamic vacuum. The appropriate amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24 (VWR Chemicals) was dissolved in 1 ml of water to obtain an impregnation solution with a concentration of precursor to deposit 2 wt% of Mo with a volume of solution corresponding to the total pore volume of the support (0.24 cm3/gsupport). After addition of the impregnation solution required to fill the total pore volume of the support, the impregnated support was stirred until a homogenous dry powder was obtained. Afterwards, the powder was dried overnight at 80 °C and finally calcined by heating it to 550 °C (2 °C/min heating ramp) under static air and holding the calcination temperature for 7 h under static air. For the sample prepared through SIE (2MoHZ-SIE), the appropriate amount of MoO3 (Fluka, 99.5 %) for a 2 wt% Mo loading was added to the H-ZSM-5 support and well-mixed using a mortar and pestle. Afterwards, the mixture was calcined at 550 °C (2 °C/min heating ramp) for 7 h in a static air furnace. 2.2 Catalyst characterization To determine the Mo content of the catalyst samples inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed. The samples were destructed in LiBO2 (Accu SPEC, analytical grade). The prepared solution was analysed with a SPECTRO CIROS CCD instrument. N2 physisorption measurements were performed at −196 °C on a 3P 400 sync gas adsorption analyzer. Before the measurement, the zeolite samples were dried overnight at 300 °C under dynamic vacuum. Specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method [39]. The total pore volume was assessed at 0.99p/p0. The micropore volume was calculated by the t-plot method using the Harkins and Jura model [40,41]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the fresh samples were collected on a Bruker D8 in Bragg-Brentano mode using Cu Kα1,2 radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) and was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Data was collected in the 2θ range from 5 to 55° with a 0.2° increment and scan speed of 2.5 s per step while the sample was rotated at 15 rpm. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) with NH3 was performed using a Micrometrics Autochem 2910 apparatus. The amount of NH3 desorbed was determined using a thermal conductivity (TCD) detector. About 100 mg of material was loaded in a quartz reactor and heated to 400 °C with a 10 °C/min ramp and held for 30 min under He flow to dry the sample. The sample was cooled to 100 °C and 20 pulses of NH3 were applied to ensure complete saturation of the acid sites. Subsequently, the sample was outgassed at 100 °C for 2 h and finally heated to 600 °C with a 5 °C/min ramp while the desorbed amount of NH3 was measured. Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Renishaw InVia Raman microscope, using 532 nm laser excitation through a × 50 objective and a 0.5 numerical aperture. Spectra were recorded between 100 and 1500 cm−1 with a 1200 l mm−1 grating, 10 s acquisition time, 1 accumulation, and a laser power output of 17.5mW. To analyze the coke content of the spent catalyst materials, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin Elmer TGA 8000 instrument. In a typical experiment between 1–3 mg of spent catalyst was loaded in a crucible and heated from 30 to 800 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of 45.0 cm3/min of air. The total amount of produced coke was calculated following Eq. (1). Before loading the catalyst material into the reactor, it was pelletized using a pressure of 2.5 bar, crushed, and sieved to obtain a sieve fraction of 212–425 µm. In a typical experiment, 300 mg of catalyst was loaded into the reactor and exposed to a flow of a 9:1 mixture of CH4/N2 with a total flow of 10 cm3/min corresponding to a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 1.2gCH4 gsample -1h−1 where N2 served as the internal standard. The solid catalyst was heated with 5 °C/min to 700 °C and kept at 700 °C for 600 min. Gaseous products were analyzed by an Interscience Compact GC. Detection and separation of the light hydrocarbons (C1–C5 fraction) was achieved with a Restek Al2O3/Na2SO4 column (30 m × 0.32 mm) coupled to a flame ionization detector (FID). Aromatic products were detected with a Restek Rtx-Wax 0.5u (15 m × 0.32 mm) column. Light gases (i.e., CH4, CO, CO2, H2, and N2) were detected using a TCD coupled to a Restek ShinCarbon ST 80/100 (2 m × 0.53 mm) column. The CH4 conversion was calculated using Eq. Afterwards the catalyst was cooled to 700 °C under N2 flow, before exposing the reduced catalyst to the 9:1 CH4/N2 mixture, which was taken as TOS = 0. Operando UV–Vis DRS data were obtained using an AvaSpec 2048L spectrometer equipped with a 100 µm slit and connected to a high-temperature UV–Vis optical fiber probe, which was used to collect spectra in diffusion reflection mode. During a typical experiment, spectra were recorded between 250–1000 nm and saved every 30 s. A dark spectrum was recorded at room temperature and the absorbance was calculated using: (5) A = log 10 ( I 0 I ) where I is the intensity spectrum recorded during the reaction, and I 0 corresponds to the intensity of the first spectrum recorded at 700 °C. Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS) analysis of the acquired operando UV–Vis DRS data was performed using the MCR-ALS GUI v4c software developed by Gorzsás et al. running in MATLAB R2021a [43]. For each experiment, all collected UV–Vis DRS data within the reaction period where combined as a single matrix. Further pre-processing included reducing the analysed spectral region to the spectral window of 220 – 800 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Operando UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy and multivariate curve resolution To assess the impact of CO pre-treatment and catalyst preparation on the catalytic activity and on the formation of intermediates, the catalyst materials were studied using operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS). In these operando spectroscopy experiments, the performance of the catalyst in terms of CH4 conversion and products yields are assessed via online gas chromatography (GC). At the same time, UV–Vis DRS data are recorded which can be correlated to catalyst performance. Operando UV–Vis DRS measurements have shown to be very useful in studying similar catalytic reactions, like the MTH process [44,45]. Various hydrocarbon species that play a role during this reaction have been identified using operando UV–Vis DRS, as shown in Scheme 2 . In the catalytic data for the 2MoHZ-IWI catalyst, the three typical MDA phases are observable, as highlighted in Fig. 1 A. Firstly, the activation period (purple) occurs. During this period, the oxidic Mo pre-catalyst gets reduced and carburized by CH4 to the active (oxy-)carbidic Mo-catalyst [21,46]. The carburization can be observed through the evolution of CO, which is the most clear indication of the activation period as well as some H2 production (Fig. 1B). During the activation period, no benzene or other aromatic products are observed. This activation is accompanied by a general increase in the UV–Vis absorbance especially in the spectral region at around 29,000 cm−1, as can be seen in Fig. 1D. Already while the catalyst is not yet fully activated (CO still observable at the reactor exit, see Fig. 1B), a slow increase in benzene formation is observed (Fig. 1A). After the activation period, the benzene yield increases further, marking the induction period of the MDA reaction. During this period the spectral feature at around 30,000 cm−1 further increases, an additional shoulder at around 38,000 cm−1 arises and an additional absorption band at around 18,000 cm−1 becomes visible. The shoulder at 38,000 cm−1 lies in the expected region of neutral (alkylated) aromatics (Scheme 2) and can probably be attributed to the formed aromatic products benzene and toluene since it is absent before the start of the induction period [35,47]. Finally, the deactivation of the catalyst material is observed, which is marked by a continuous decrease in both CH4 conversion and benzene yield. The spectra from this period are mainly governed by an increase of absorbance below 20,000 cm−1 which is the region where polyaromatic hydrocarbons are typically observed (Scheme 2). In literature, there is consensus that these species lead to micropore blockage and may be the cause of catalyst deactivation [9,30,35,47]. Although we can see an increase in absorbance at some wavenumbers at certain reaction times, there are no clear bands observable, due to convolution of the various hydrocarbon species. Therefore, MCR-ALS was used to distinguish spectral contributions and their behaviour with time on stream. The temporal contributions of the obtained spectral components during the experiment for the 2MoHZ-IWI catalyst are presented in Fig. 1C and E, respectively. For this experiment, a minimum of three MCR components is necessary to describe the variance in the UV–Vis DRS data sufficiently. As is apparent from Fig. 1C, the purple component has its main contribution only at the beginning of the experiment and its maximum contribution aligns well with the maximum conversion of CH4, while for the rest of the experiment, its contribution is negligible. This temporal evolution fits well with the observed activation period of the MDA reaction and was therefore assigned as the activation component. The activation component’s main spectral features are centered at around 25,000 cm−1 (Fig. 1E) and likely arise from the formation of oxy-carbidic Mo sites, which form during the activation period, as shown in previous studies [21,22]. After the maximum methane conversion was achieved, a second component (light blue) begins to dominate. Interestingly, this component exhibits almost no contribution before the activation period, while a steady increase until a maximum is observed after the catalyst has been activated. This behaviour aligns well with the expected induction period of the reaction. Furthermore, the component mimics the trend of the benzene yield rather well, as shown in Fig. S6. Therefore, the light blue component was assigned to the induction and active period of the catalyst. The induction/active component exhibits high absorption at around 35,000 cm−1, which probably originates from (alkylated) aromatic products, like benzene and toluene (Scheme 2). Interestingly, also high absorbance in the regions of mono- and dienylic cations (33,000–27,000 cm−1) and charged alkylated benzenes (27,000–25,000 cm−1) is observable [35,36,47]. Mono- and dienylic cations and charged alkylated benzenes have been identified to be important hydrocarbon pool species in the formation of small olefins which can further cyclize into aromatics in the MTH reaction [28,48]. Based on our findings, it is plausible that the observed hydrocarbons play a similar role in the MDA reaction. The last component (grey) exhibits a steady increase with time on stream and is especially dominant in the deactivation regime of the reaction. While similar spectral features are present for the grey component as for the induction/active component, a strong increase in absorbance at around 18,000 cm−1 is visible, which is typical for polyaromatic species (Scheme 2), which are believed to be coke precursors leading to pore blockage [9,13]. Therefore, the grey component was assigned as the deactivation component. 3.2 Elimination of the activation phase To verify the assignment of the activation component, a CO pre-treatment was carried out prior to exposing the solid catalyst to CH4 to eliminate the activation phase. A prior study demonstrated that applying a CO pre-treatment results in an active catalyst without the formation of carbonaceous deposits [16]. The resulting catalytic methane conversion and benzene yield without and with CO pre-treatment at 750 °C are compared in Fig. 2 A and 2B, respectively. There is no delay in benzene production for the catalyst pre-treated in CO whereas a delay is observed for the catalyst that did not undergo a CO pre-treatment (Fig. 2A, B). In the context of the three typical phases of the MDA reaction, this means that the activation period is not observed because it already occurred during CO pre-treatment. When performing MCR-ALS on the dataset of the operando UV–Vis DRS data of the reaction with pre-treatment, interestingly only two components were necessary to describe the variance in the dataset instead of three (Fig. 2C, D). When an additional component is included, it cannot be related to any of the observed catalytic trends in the MDA reaction (Fig. S7). The missing component for the pre-treated sample is ascribed to the activation period since none of the determined components exhibits a main contribution around the maximum methane conversion, which would be typical for an activation component. The fact that the activation component in the operando UV–Vis DRS data set is missing matches well with a study that already showed that the activation occurred during the CO pre-treatment [16]. The last obtained spectrum of the catalyst material during the CO pre-treatment as well as the activation component for the non-pre-treated sample are depicted in Fig. 3 . It is noteworthy that the spectra share similarities: both spectra contain a band at around 25,000 cm−1 which is likely due to the formation of (oxy-)carbidic Mo-sites, formed during the activation of the material. However, the spectral component of the activation period of the sample that did not undergo a CO pre-treatment shows higher absorbance between 25,000 and 40,000 cm−1. Absorbance in this region is related to mono- and dienylic cations, charged alkylated benzenes and neutral aromatics. This indicates that during the activation in CH4, some hydrocarbon species are already formed on the catalyst surface, resulting in an overlap of the activation and induction/active phase. Both the absence of a component with the contribution in the activation period for the pre-treated catalyst (Fig. S7), as well as the similarities of the purple component observed on the untreated sample with the recorded spectrum right after the pre-treatment, corroborate the assignment of the purple component to the activation phase. The CO pre-treatment does not seem to have an impact on the induction/active phase. Only minor differences in the spectral shape of the induction/active component are observed among the experiments with and without pre-treatment, which suggests that the pre-treatment does not influence the initially formed MDA intermediates nor the further MDA reaction mechanism. Furthermore, pre-treatment with CO does not seem to significantly impact the deactivation of the catalyst. The most dominant spectral features of the deactivation component lie in the region of polyaromatic coke (precursors), suggesting a similar deactivation process of coke accumulation within the pores of the zeolite support. The benzene yields observed are similar, but the higher CH4 conversion of the 2MoHZ-IWI CO catalyst would indicate higher coking on the pre-treated sample. However, the coke content on the 2MoHZ-IWI CO catalyst is lower compared to the 2MoHZ-IWI catalyst as was determined with TGA (Fig. S9 and Table S4). 3.3 Influence of catalyst preparation The influence of the catalyst preparation method on the MDA reaction was investigated by comparing the operando UV–Vis DRS results of the 2MoHZ-IWI and 2MoHZ-SIE catalysts (Fig. 4 ). While the catalysts have a similar weight loading of Mo, the nature of the active sites created is quite different·NH3-TPD revealed a much stronger decrease in acidity for 2MoHZ-IWI than for 2MoHZ-SIE (Table S2 and Fig. S2), which is likely due to the high Mo dispersion on the IWI catalyst after replacement of the acidic proton in the zeolite by Mo. In contrast, clustering occurs during synthesis with SIE. This observation is supported by Raman spectroscopy, where smaller Mo nanoparticles were observed on the 2MoHZ-SIE catalyst (Fig. S4). However, these particles could not be observed with X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. S3). An earlier study already showed that preparing a Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst via either IWI or SIE leads to these differences in Mo-species [49]. Since it is known that the presence of bigger Mo-clusters impacts the deactivation [31], and thus the formation of hydrocarbons on the surface, this set of catalysts allows us to showcase the strengths of the operando UV–Vis spectroscopy in combination with MCR. The methane conversion and benzene yield of the 2MoHZ-IWI and 2MoHZ-SIE are shown in Fig. 4A and B, respectively. Maximum methane conversion is reached at the same time for the two catalyst materials indicating that the activation proceeds at a similar speed. In addition, the spectral component corresponding to the activation period has a similar shape (Fig. 4C and D), indicating that the active sites are similar in nature. Also, the time behaviour of the spectral components of the two different materials is similar (Fig. 4E and F). However, a higher methane conversion is observed for 2MoHZ–SIE, while the reverse is true for the benzene yield. This indicates that more coke deposits are formed on the 2MoHZ-SIE catalyst. This was confirmed with thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) performed on the catalyst material after MDA reaction (Fig. S9, Table S4) as well as with N2 physisorption, as the BET surface area, pore volume and micropore volume are decreased more for the SIE sample compared to the IWI sample. This indicates that the zeolite pores are blocked to a greater extent for the SIE sample by coke and/or Mo clusters. It highlights that the deactivation is more severe if the Mo/ZSM-5 is prepared through SIE. Interestingly, both catalyst materials exhibit a similar deactivation rate until the end of the experiment, indicated by the similar rate of decrease in benzene formation. The higher deactivation rate for the 2MoHZ–SIE catalyst is probably related to the presence of Mo nanoparticles on this sample. The presence of nanoparticles on the 2MoHZ-SIE catalyst leads to an increase in coke production, while deactivation on 2MoHZ-IWI likely proceeds through clustering of the initially well-dispersed Mo [31]. This interpretation is supported by the difference in the deactivation component between the two catalysts. The higher coking rate is evidenced by the fact that 2MoHZ–SIE shows a more intense feature than 2MoHZ-IWI in the region corresponding to polyaromatic species (above 20,000 cm−1, Fig. 4B and 4E). The loss of the active Mo species through clustering is supported by the fact that the contribution of the spectral component corresponding to the activation period decreases faster for 2MoHZ-IWI than for 2MoHZ–SIE (Fig. 4E and F). Therefore, the observations from the operando UV–Vis data set, used in combination with MCR, are in line with observations from prior studies [31,49]. 4 Conclusions By combining operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) with Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS), we show that it is possible to disentangle and separately study the three reaction phases of the Methane Dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction over a Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst material. We identified three MCR components related to the activation, induction, and deactivation. As shown in earlier work, the activation phase can be eliminated when the catalyst is pre-treated in CO [46]. This is in alignment with our operando data since only two MCR components were required to describe the operando UV–Vis DRS data set. During the induction/active period, we observed the formation of Hydrocarbon Pool (HCP) species, such as mono- and dienylic cations and charged and neutral alkylated aromatics. Hydrocarbon pool species act as intermediates in the Methanol-to-Hydrocarbons (MTH) reaction and based on our findings it is plausible they also play a role in the formation of aromatics in the MDA process. The HCP species were already present during the activation phase when the catalyst was activated in CH4 whereas these species were not formed during the CO pre-treatment but only afterwards when the catalyst was exposed to methane. Independent of the synthesis method or pre-treatment used, the HCP species could be observed for both the induction and active periods of the MDA reaction. This indicates that these species might be important intermediates towards the formation of aromatics or other larger HCP species. Finally, the deactivation of the MDA process is governed by the accumulation of large polyaromatic species. Furthermore, we found that the catalyst preparation impacts the Mo-dispersion, but it does not impact the activation or induction/active phase. However, the catalyst preparation does impact the deactivation. The 2MoHZ–SIE catalyst has a higher selectivity towards coke which is reflected in the deactivation component which has a higher contribution below 20000 cm−1. Overall, we have shown that operando UV–Vis DRS in combination with MCR-ALS is a powerful analytical tool to spectroscopically investigate catalytic trends during the MDA process. coredata.dc:description: Methane Dehydroaromatization (MDA) is proposed as a possible way to valorize stranded natural gas, e.g., arising during crude oil drilling. In this study, we used operando UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) in combination with Multivariate Curve Resolution Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS) to distinguish the MDA reaction phases of activation, induction, and deactivation. We identified three spectral components, which describe these distinct reaction phases. When the catalyst was activated in CO, two spectral components alone sufficiently described the operando UV–Vis DRS data. We further found that the preparation method of the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst has little influence on the observed spectral features. However, the different preparation methods impact the dispersion of Mo, resulting in faster deactivation for the catalyst with more Mo-clusters compared to the catalyst with a higher Mo dispersion. This study shows that operando UV–Vis DRS in combination with the MCR-ALS methodology is a powerful analytical tool to disentangle and study the three MDA reaction phases.
